qas.question: Czechs immigrated from Europe to the U.S. primary from 1848 to when?
What kind of language is Czech in U.S. schools?
What states have large communities of Czech Americans?
What is the most commonly spoken non-English language at homes nationwide in the U.S.?
How many Americans spoke Czech as their first language as of 2009?
What kind of language is Swedish in US schools?
What states have large communities of Swedish Americans?

plausible_answers.text: the most-common language spoken at home

qas.question: What was reported about Swedish in the 2009 US Census?
How many Americans spoke Swedish in 2009?
What place is Spanish as the language being spoken as a first language nationwide?

context: Immigration of Czechs from Europe to the United States occurred primarily from 1848 to <a0_0>1914<a0_0/>. Czech is <a1_0><b5_0>a Less Commonly Taught Language<b5_0/><a1_0/> in U.S. schools, and is taught at Czech heritage centers. Large communities of Czech Americans live in the states of <a2_0><b6_0>Texas, Nebraska and Wisconsin<b6_0/><a2_0/>. In the 2000 United States Census, Czech was reported as <b7_0>the most-common language spoken at home<b7_0/> (besides English) in Valley, Butler and Saunders Counties, Nebraska and Republic County, Kansas. With the exception of <a3_0>Spanish<a3_0/> (the non-English language most commonly spoken at home nationwide), Czech was the most-common home language in over a dozen additional counties in Nebraska, Kansas, Texas, North Dakota and Minnesota. As of 2009, <a4_0><b8_0>70,500<b8_0/><a4_0/> Americans spoke Czech as their first language (<b9_0>49th place<b9_0/> nationwide, behind Turkish and ahead of Swedish).
